Dear Ms. Pettway:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
December 7, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statues except for the
following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 (4) Personnel records.
(4) An agency shall maintain an orientation
and training record for staff members.
1 of 5 personnel records reviewed did not have documentation of orientation
training for a staff member.
CPA RULE 400.12418 (2) (a) Development of service plan
(2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents,
as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
1 of 1 independent living case record reviewed the service plan was late.
CPA RULE 400.12418 (2)(b) Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
2

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
3 of 6 open foster care cases reviewed had late service plans and did not
meet the 90-day required for this rule.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. Renewal
Inspection dated 10/13/22, CAP approved 10/27/22. The agency was in violation
with Rules 400.12326 Borrowed home, 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy,
400.12418 Development of service plans and FOM Policy 722-08C PATP, and
FOM Policy 801-3 Medical Passport. There were repeat violations for this
licensing period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was discussed with the Chief Administrator
onsite on 12/5/2023. She stated staff turnover and new staff not being properly
trained had the greatest impact on violations cited during the last review period.
She stated from August 2022 through July 2023 there were a total of 12
resignations in child welfare. She stated the CAP implementation has had a
positive impact on the agency due to supervisor/staff weekly supervision meetings
and trainings where the supervisors are discussing non-compliances and repeat
violations. She said staff are encouraged during this time to ask questions for
clarification of rules and policies. She said her goal is to make sure the staff are
feeling supportive in their everyday activities and understanding the importance of
CPA rules and policies. The CA indicated that monitoring and discussing KPI’s
with staff on a regular basis has shown to be beneficial and continues to reflect
positively in the agency KPI metrics. She said the agency has filled the vacant
positions and she is confident that several areas will improve over the next review
period.
Financial Overview
4

The agency annual audit by an independent certified public accountant and the
agency annual budget was reviewed. There were no concerns noted.
Staff Interviews
Licensing, adoption, and foster care staff were interviewed onsite on 12/5/2023.
Staff were consistent in stating they love the environment of working at the agency
and feel supported by their coworkers, supervisors, and the administration. One
worker reported if she could enhance the agency, she would offer the families
incentives such as the opportunity of having their house clean for a month to show
appreciation of working with the youth placed in their homes. Another change the
staff suggested would be having the opportunity to work mobile more often. The
staff reported they enjoy having potlucks with one another and getting ideas for
their most difficult cases.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no areas of safety concerns noted in the areas of the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were 3 Safety Alerts.
Safety Alert 1:
Concern:
The caregivers did not have any working smoke or carbon monoxide detectors in
their home.
Resolution:
Agency foster care specialist visited the home on 8/30/2023 and provided 3 smoke
detectors combo with carbon monoxide to the caregivers. The smoke detectors
combo was installed on 8/31/2023. Installation was confirmed by the agency foster
care specialist on 8/31/23 along with photo verification.
Safety Alert 2:
Concern:
The caregivers have a swimming pool. There is no alarm on the door that leads to
the pool.
Resolution:
The caregivers installed a door alarm on the door that leads to the backyard area
where the pool is located. The foster care specialist verified the lock on the door on
8/28/23. Photo verification was provided of the lock on the door.
Safety Alert 3:
5

Concern:
The caregivers have an inground swimming pool. There is a fence around the
backyard, however a barrier is recommended around the pool. A safety plan for
activities involving the pool is needed.
Resolution:
The caregivers installed door alarms and a padlock on the gate that leads to the pool
in the backyard. The caregivers signed the safety plan and agreed to abide by the
safety plan. This was verified by the agency foster care specialist on 9/11/23. The
caregivers have a fence around the backyard area, door alarm, padlock, pool cover
and adult supervision when the pool is in use. The signed safety plan was signed on
9/11/2023. The safety plan and photos were provided.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
